Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: A safety audit is scheduled shortly, and minor issues with equipment have already been flagged.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes, the screen lighting up with a message from my stepmother: “How was your day? Did you eat? Call me when you can.” I knew she expected a quick reply, maybe even a call, to reassure her that I was okay and to keep up the daily rhythm we’d established since I moved in. But I was hunched over the centrifuge, frowning at the error code blinking on its display. The safety audit was in two hours, and I still had to recalibrate the pH meter and double-check the chemical storage logs. My supervisor had made it clear—any slip-up could mean a failed audit, and the lab’s reputation was on the line. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides: the warmth and concern of my family, the cold, precise demands of my work. My fingers hovered over my phone, torn between sending a reassuring message and diving back into the tangle of wires and protocols. The clock on the wall ticked louder, and I could feel my chest tightening as I tried to decide which world needed me more in that moment.
